contextId.occurrenceNote: a polite way of saying "do not to kill us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.glQuote: spare the lives ... save us from death

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "a hand is laid upon" is a polite way of referring to causing someone injury. Alternate translation: "if we cause injury to any" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.glQuote: if a hand is laid upon any

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "fallen" is a euphemism for dying. Also, "the edge of the sword" represents whole swords, and swords represent either battle or the army of Israel. Alternate translation: "had died in battle" or "had died when the army of Israel attacked them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: had fallen by the edge of the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joshua uses a polite term to refer to his death. Alternate translation: "I am going to die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.glQuote: I am going the way of all the earth
